item.title: Facebook's had a bad year, but the users are staying.
item.description:

But with every new announcement and report, it seems that it isn‚Äôt quite enough for people to part ways with the social network for good. After many of these events, we ran surveys to determine if it they were enough for users to delete or deactivate their accounts, and every time, there was a consensus: ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôll stay.‚Äù

This stuff depresses me and yet‚Ä¶I‚Äôm still technically on Facebook. There are a couple of groups I use there and I do some social media tasks for my church. I don‚Äôt really get value out it, certainly less than other places, and the value I do get out of it could be replaced by alternatives‚Ä¶.and yet I‚Äôm still there.

item.description:
https://brooksreview.net/2018/11/building-technology-for-good/

I‚Äôm not sure there is a clear answer, however my gut says that Facebook is more net negative than iPhone. I wonder how much of that could have been avoided if more consideration was given while building out the Facebook, as was given when Apple built iPhone.

This is an interesting link and comment by @ben and I wanted to continue that thought by suggesting the opposite of Facebook‚Äôs approach. Move slow and Mend things. Take your time, consider the impact of your actions and the unintended negative side effects.

I wonder what this would also look like in my personal life. If I didn‚Äôt jump on the latest hype train but waited to let other -suckers- people test them out first and find the issues. If I were more critical of what I let impact my life than I currently am?

item.title: Come for the Topic, Stay for the Hosts?
item.description:
I remember hearing Merlin Mann make this statement on back to work some five years ago or so. At the time I nodded my head in agreement, but recently I‚Äôve been questioning this statement a bit.

I initially accepted it as that had been my response with every podcast I listened to, I found them from the topic, but I stayed because I enjoyed the hosts views and the way they talked. In fact, I suspect one of my favorite podcasts of all time had a lot to do with the wonderful timbre of the main host‚Äôs voice. As further proof I could point to podcasts where I had tried but stopped listening to because I didn‚Äôt enjoy the hosts, and Bionic/bonanza which started as an android podcast but descended (well really ascended) into a podcast about secret volcano bases, Elon Musk‚Äôs plans to take over the world, round the world races and saved by the bell.

But lately I have counter points. Podcasts where I enjoy the hosts (as I have/do listen to their other podcasts), but they have moved away from the original topic and so it no longer appeals to me. Or another podcast where I enjoyed these hosts talking about this topic but now they‚Äôve moved into a more generic topic, they don‚Äôt seem to be as interesting or original.

While I think Merlin‚Äôs statement is a great generalization, I now believe a great podcast is a combination of many factors including the topic, the hosts perspectives and views, their interaction off each other and technical factors like good sound recording.

item.title: I still love paper
item.description:
In many ways I think my attachment for my smartphone is born out of my same attachment for notebooks and pens. The later preceded the former when my father gifted me a translucent purple covered a6 pocket notebook at high school. The point was to write my tasks and assignments so I wouldn‚Äôt have to rely on my very fallible memory and instead stay organized and on top of things.

The reason it stuck was because I also had a set of bright neon pens that I used to reimagine the cover and pages inside.

Nethertheless, the notebook did it‚Äôs job and lead to a transformative moment in my life. I can divide my life into the disorganized forgetful mess I was before I had my first notebook, and the increasingly organizing and effective person I am still becoming since then.

When I went looking to get my first smartphone, the one feature I wanted was a good calendar so I could replace my paper one. I didn‚Äôt care about any games or the camera, they were of far lesser importance than the calendar and notes. To this day, my calendar, task manager and notes app are in my top five most used apps (the camera and podcast app are also present).

But despite the usefulness of these applications, there‚Äôs still something delightful about paper and pen. The blank page is a creative curse, but it can also be an inspiring invitation.

A blank page can become a picture, a task list, a quick doodle for no reason, a profound quote to be remembered, or a brain dump of ideas and concerns regarding a project.

As great as my iPad Pro and Apple Pencil are, they aren‚Äôt the same as a good pen and notebook.

item.title: The Annoying Trend of Making Stuff About Making Stuff
item.description:
One of the things that annoys me the most about the modern internet landscape is how much stuff is made about making stuff. Especially when it is the same form as the thing which is being made.

  • Blog posts about writing blog posts
  • Youtube Videos about making YouTube videos
  • Podcasts about podcasts (this is probably the least offender) I now wonder if this is part of the inherit nature of being an indie creator. If you become successful and go full time, then the thing you are making becomes your full time job. What else can you write about‚Ä¶except writing about running your job.

Of course, it‚Äôs not inevitable and I think the best online content avoids this pitfall. CGP Grey‚Äôs great videos aren‚Äôt about how he makes his videos, Amanda Palmer‚Äôs music isn‚Äôt about making music and Andy Weir wrote a great book about a man on mars on his blog.

My challenge to myself is to focus more on making things, and not making things about making things.

Imagine buying a WordPress theme with a ‚Äúlifetime license‚Äù, now imagine not getting any updates in the last year and half after a few since it‚Äôs launch. NOW imagine there is a new version of that theme where you have to purchase a new ‚Äúlifetime‚Äù license.

Today, as digital tools get cheaper and more widespread, a new gap is appearing:

In the past in Europe, pale skin was seen as attractive, as people who were suntanned worked in the fields. Now, the reverse is true as it is a sign of not working to have travel abroad and obtained your tan. item.title: Where are the fresh blogging opinions üîó
item.description:
Daring Fireball: Dan Frakes Goes to Apple as Mac App Store Editor

Cross linking between blogs has nearly dried up. It‚Äôs almost impossible to find new opinions because everyone links to the same three websites, like I‚Äôm doing now.

A lot of voices have moved on to podcasting. Frankly, as someone that also podcasts, it‚Äôs easier and there‚Äôs less accountability than with blogging. Today, I also see a lot of thoughtful people writing on Discord groups. There‚Äôs little value in blogging unless you just like to practice writing in public.

This is one of those articles that starts discussing one issue, but the commentary actually is far more interesting than the inital discussion (In my opinion at least). I wonder how accurate Gabe‚Äôs prognosis is (that new voices are podcasting). While I see truth in this, I also think one of the issues is that online writing has become quite formulaic and people simply copy others ideas without offering something fresh. No one could be a full time blogger in the early days of online writing, now there are a host of them (and companies that employ writers) who‚Äôs opinions are well regarded. I‚Äôve started (and stopped) following some new writers as I realised they were just repeating others points. At the same time, I have discovered fresh voices who offer something unique.

  • Rose Orchard
  • Denny Henke
  • Zsolt Benke
  • Greg Morris
  • Andy Nicolaides Admittedly some of those same voices also use their litteral voices for podcasts too, but that doesn‚Äôt stop the fact that they are adding their unique writing voice. Really, it‚Äôs not that writing is in decline, it‚Äôs that more writers are also professional podcasters.
